                  Introduction and Summary

                  Introduction
                  This report presents the results of a traffic impact study for the proposed Vast Oak and University
                  District LLC Mixed-Use Development in the City of Rohnert Park, California. Figure 1 shows a map of
                  the study area vicinity. Figure 2 shows the project site plan.

                  The proposed project would be developed on five currently vacant parcels (VO West, VO
                  Central, VO East, VO North and UD LLC) within the University District Specific Plan (UDSP)
                  area. The parcels are located along Rohnert Park Expressway north of the Sonoma State
                  University (SSU) campus and Green Music Center (GMC) and west of Petaluma Hill Road. The
                  project consists of an amendment to the approved UDSP to allow for some adjustments in
                  residential product types. The level of development proposed for this project is consistent with
                  the level of development contemplated in the 2006 UDSP environmental impact report (EIR).
                  The full-build proposed project will consist of 1,236 single-family homes ranging from low- to
                  high-density, 218 below market rate (BMR) apartments), and 100,000 square feet of
                  neighborhood-serving commercial retail (VO East). The project would be built in five phases, and
                  the parcels are expected to be completed in the following order: VO West, VO Central, VO
                  East, VO North and UD LLC. According to the site plan, the project would provide multiple
                  access points to Rohnert Park Expressway and Keiser Avenue.

                  For purposes of direct comparison with the 2006 UDSP EIR, the proposed project unit count
                  includes 191 single-family units proposed to be built on three non-VO/UD LLC parcels within the
                  UDSP: Linden, Gee, and Cotati-Rohnert Park Unified School District (CRPUSD).

                  This report includes an analysis of potential project traffic impacts; evaluation of potential
                  mitigations to address these impacts; and existing pedestrian, bicycle, and transit conditions. The
                  report also discusses whether the proposed project would cause any new significant impacts or
                  cause a substantial increase in the severity of the impacts that were disclosed in the 2006 UDSP
                  EIR.

                  Summary
                  With the application of internal trip discounts to all project land uses and pass-by trip discounts to
                  all commercial retail land uses according to the UDSP EIR and Trip Generation Handbook guidance,
                  the proposed project is expected to generate approximately 16,274 weekday daily trips (8,137 both
                  inbound and outbound), 1,118 weekday a.m. peak hour trips (303 inbound, 815 outbound), and
                  1,662 weekday p.m. peak hour trips (1,016 inbound, 646 outbound). For purposes of direct
                  comparison with the 2006 UDSP EIR, these trip totals include the 191 single-family units proposed
                  on three non-VO/UD LLC parcels located within the UDSP: Linden, Gee, and Cotati-Rohnert Park
                  Unified School District (CRPUSD). When compared to the total project trips analyzed in the 2006
                  UDSP EIR, the current project results in 2,361 fewer daily trips and 181 fewer p.m. peak hour trips.

                  Under Existing Conditions, all intersections are operating within acceptable LOS standards, with
                  the exception of the northbound North SSU Access stop-controlled movement at Rohnert Park
                  Expressway, which operates at LOS E during the a.m. peak hour and LOS F during the p.m. peak
                  hour. Also, the Adobe Road / Petaluma Hill Road intersection operates at LOS F during the p.m.
                  peak hour.


                 Final Report ­ Traffic Impact Study for University District LLC & Vast Oak Properties              Page 1
                 in the City of Rohnert Park                                                               January 3, 2014
        TJKM
Transportation
   Consultants

                  Under Existing Conditions, both US 101 study freeway segments are operating at LOS C in the
                  southbound direction during the p.m. peak hour. In the northbound direction, the freeway segment
                  of Rohnert Park Expressway and Santa Rosa Avenue is operating at LOS F during the p.m. peak
                  hour.

                  With the addition of project traffic under Existing plus Project Conditions, significant impacts are
                  expected at the following intersections:
                      ·    Snyder Lane / Keiser Avenue: LOS D/C to LOS F/F (AM/PM) for the minor westbound
                           approach. This is a significant impact based on applicable LOS criteria. The UDSP prescribes
                           installation of a traffic signal (TRA-4a), which if implemented as a mitigation would improve
                           the intersection to LOS B/A (AM/PM), thereby resulting in a less than significant impact,
                           consistent with the UDSP EIR.
                      ·    Rohnert Park Expressway / North SSU Access: LOS E/F to LOS F/F for the minor
                           northbound approach. This is a significant impact based on applicable LOS criteria. The
                           UDSP prescribes installation of a westbound left turn pocket and two-way left-turn lane
                           (TRA-1a) plus a traffic signal (TRA-7a). If both mitigations are implemented, the
                           intersection would improve to LOS C/C (AM/PM), thereby resulting in a less than
                           significant impact consistent with the UDSP EIR.
                      ·    Adobe Road / Petaluma Hill Road: with the addition of project traffic, this intersection
                           would continue to operate unacceptably at LOS F during the p.m. peak hour, with an
                           increase of 24.1 seconds in delay. Since delay would increase by more than five seconds
                           under an unacceptable LOS F condition, this is a significant impact consistent with the
                           UDSP EIR. If an additional through lane were added in both the northbound and
                           southbound directions of Petaluma Hill Road, the p.m. peak hour service level would
                           improve to LOS D. However, this improvement is subject to a feasibility evaluation, and
                           Sonoma County has not identified this or any other transportation improvement for this
                           intersection. Therefore, consistent with the UDSP EIR, this impact is considered significant
                           and unavoidable. Consistent with UDSP EIR mitigation TRA-9a, TJKM recommends
                           coordination between Sonoma County and the City of Rohnert Park to determine a fair-
                           share portion of funds to alleviate congestion at this intersection and, if appropriate,
                           collection of a fair-share allocation from the project sponsor.

                  With the addition of project volumes under Existing plus Project Conditions, both US 101 study
                  freeway segments are expected to continue operating at LOS C in the southbound direction during
                  the p.m. peak hour. In the northbound direction, both freeway segments are expected to operate
                  at LOS E or worse during the p.m. peak hour, which is a significant impact. Given that there are no
                  known freeway capacity improvements that would result in acceptable operation in the future, and
                  subsequently no means for the proposed project to contribute a fair-share payment for impacts to
                  the US 101 freeway, these impacts are considered significant and unavoidable.

                  Under 2020 Baseline Conditions, all intersections are expected to operate within acceptable LOS
                  standards, with the following exceptions:
                      ·    Snyder Lane / Keiser Avenue (LOS F both peak hours for westbound approach)
                      ·    Petaluma Hill Road / Keiser Avenue (LOS F both peak hours for eastbound approach)
                      ·    Rohnert Park Expressway / Snyder Lane (LOS E during a.m. peak hour)
                      ·    Rohnert Park Expressway / North SSU Access (LOS F both peak hours)

                 Final Report ­ Traffic Impact Study for University District LLC & Vast Oak Properties              Page 2
                 in the City of Rohnert Park                                                               January 3, 2014
        TJKM
Transportation
   Consultants

                      ·    E. Cotati Avenue / Old Redwood Highway (LOS E during p.m. peak hour)
                      ·    Adobe Road / Petaluma Hill Road (LOS F both peak hours)
                      ·    Main Street / Old Redwood Highway (LOS F during a.m. peak hour and LOS E during p.m.
                           peak hour

                  Under 2020 Baseline Conditions, both US 101 study freeway segments are expected to operate at
                  LOS D or better in the southbound direction during the p.m. peak hour. In the northbound
                  direction, both freeway segments are expected to operate at LOS E or worse.

                  Under 2020 plus Project Conditions, the addition of project traffic is expected to result in
                  significant impacts at the following intersections:
                      ·    Snyder Lane / Keiser Avenue (LOS F both peak hours for westbound approach with added
                           average delay). This is a significant impact given that additional delay would be added to an
                           intersection already operating at LOS F in the 2020 baseline condition. With the
                           implementation of the prescribed UDSP EIR improvement of a traffic signal (TRA-4a),
                           service levels would improve to LOS B during both peak hours. The result would be a less
                           than significant impact. The impact and mitigation are consistent with the UDSP EIR.
                      ·    Petaluma Hill Road / Keiser Avenue (LOS F both peak hours for eastbound approach with
                           added average delay). This is a significant impact given that additional delay would be added
                           to an intersection already operating at LOS F in the 2020 baseline condition. With the
                           implementation of the prescribed UDSP EIR improvements of separate left and right turn
                           lanes for the eastbound Keiser Avenue approach, a center turn lane on Petaluma Hill Road
                           adjacent to Keiser Avenue, and signalization of the intersection (TRA-5a,5b, and 14a
                           respectively), service levels would improve to LOS B during both peak hours. The result
                           would be a less than significant impact. The impact and mitigation are consistent with the
                           UDSP EIR.
                      ·    Rohnert Park Expressway / Snyder Lane (LOS D to LOS E during both peak hours). This is
                           a significant impact. With the implementation of the prescribed UDSP EIR improvements to
                           widen Snyder Lane between Keiser Avenue and Southwest Boulevard and to reconfigure
                           the Rohnert Park Expressway / Snyder Lane intersection (TRA-6a and 6b, respectively),
                           service levels are expected to improve to LOS C during both peak hours, resulting in a less
                           than significant impact. The impact and mitigation are consistent with the UDSP EIR.
                      ·    Rohnert Park Expressway / North SSU Access (LOS F during both peak hours with added
                           average delay). This is a significant impact. With the UDSP mitigation (TRA-7a) of installing
                           a traffic signal and associated geometric improvements, service levels are expected to
                           improve to LOS C during both peak hours, resulting in a less than significant impact. The
                           impact and mitigation are consistent with the UDSP EIR.
                      ·    Rohnert Park Expressway / Petaluma Hill Road (change from acceptable LOS C to
                           unacceptable LOS E during both peak hours). This change in LOS represents a significant
                           impact. With the UDSP mitigation of adding an eastbound lane to allow for exclusive left
                           and right turn lanes at the intersection and an exclusive southbound right turn lane TRA-
                           8a), service levels are expected to improve to LOS C during both peak hours, resulting in a
                           less than significant impact. The impact and mitigation are consistent with the UDSP EIR.
                      ·    E. Cotati Avenue / Old Redwood Highway (LOS D/E to LOS E/F). With the addition of
                           project traffic, service levels would worsen from LOS D to E during the a.m. peak hour and
                           delay would increase under the LOS E condition during the p.m. peak hour. With the

                 Final Report ­ Traffic Impact Study for University District LLC & Vast Oak Properties              Page 3
                 in the City of Rohnert Park                                                               January 3, 2014
        TJKM
Transportation
   Consultants

                           addition of a second southbound left turn lane, service levels are expected to improve to
                           LOS D during both peak hours. However, this improvement is not programmed by the
                           City of Cotati and is subject to a feasibility analysis. Therefore, this impact remains
                           significant and unavoidable. Consistent with UDSP EIR mitigation TRA-18a, TJKM
                           recommends coordination between the Cities of Rohnert Park and Cotati to determine a
                           fair-share portion of funds to alleviate congestion at this intersection and, if appropriate, to
                           collect a fair-share allocation from the project sponsor.
                      ·    Adobe Road / Petaluma Hill Road (LOS F both peak hours with added average delay). With
                           the addition of project traffic, delay would worsen and exacerbate LOS F baseline
                           conditions, which would be a significant impact. A mitigation consisting of a second
                           southbound left turn lane, widened westbound approach with left turn and shared through-
                           right turn lanes, and an added northbound through lane would mitigate this condition to an
                           acceptable LOS D during both peak hours. However, this improvement is not programmed
                           by Sonoma County and is subject to a feasibility analysis. Therefore, this impact remains
                           significant and unavoidable. Consistent with UDSP EIR mitigation TRA-9a, TJKM
                           recommends coordination between Sonoma County and the City of Rohnert Park to
                           determine a fair-share portion of funds to alleviate congestion at this intersection and, if
                           appropriate, collection of a fair-share allocation from the project sponsor.
                      ·    Main Street / Old Redwood Highway (LOS F both peak hours with added average delay).
                           With the addition of project traffic, delay would worsen and exacerbate LOS F/E (AM/PM)
                           baseline conditions. This is a significant impact. A mitigation consisting of a second
                           southbound through lane and second northbound through lane is expected to result in an
                           acceptable LOS C during both peak hours. However, this improvement is not programmed
                           by Sonoma County and is subject to a feasibility analysis. Therefore, this impact remains
                           significant and unavoidable. Consistent with UDSP EIR mitigation TRA-9a, TJKM
                           recommends coordination between Sonoma County and the City of Rohnert Park to
                           determine a fair-share portion of funds to alleviate congestion at this intersection and, if
                           appropriate, collection of a fair-share allocation from the project sponsor.

                  With the addition of project volumes under Cumulative plus Project conditions, both US 101 study
                  freeway segments are expected to continue operating at LOS D or better in the southbound
                  direction during the p.m. peak hour. In the northbound direction, both freeway segments are
                  expected to operate at LOS E or worse during the p.m. peak hour, which is a significant impact.
                  Given that there are no known freeway capacity improvements that would result in acceptable
                  operation in the future, and subsequently no means for the proposed project to contribute a fair-
                  share payment for impacts to the US 101 freeway, these impacts are considered significant and
                  unavoidable.

                  The bicycle lanes proposed within the project site adheres to the goals of the Rohnert Park
                  General Plan, as they will connect with proposed bicycle lanes along Rohnert Park Expressway
                  adjacent to the project site. The proposed Class I bikeway along Hinebaugh Creek that runs
                  through the project site follows the goal of linking residential areas to open space areas.

                  Overall, the proposed project is not expected to result in any new or substantially worse traffic
                  impacts when compared to the traffic impacts from the UDSP as analyzed in the 2006 UDSP EIR.

                  Intersection Analysis Methodology

                  Study Methodology
                  Consistent with the 2006 UDSP EIR traffic analysis methodology, TJKM evaluated traffic conditions
                  at 13 existing study intersections during typical weekday a.m. and p.m. peak hours. In addition, two
                  project-only study intersections were analyzed that were not evaluated in the 2006 UDSP EIR. The
                  study intersections and their associated traffic controls are as follows:
                      1. Petaluma Hill Road / Snyder Lane (signalized ­ Sonoma County)
                      2. Snyder Lane / Keiser Avenue (stop control on Keiser)
                      3. Petaluma Hill Road / Keiser Avenue (stop control on Keiser)
                      4. U.S. 101 Southbound Ramps / Rohnert Park Expressway (signalized - Caltrans)
                      5. U.S. 101 Northbound Ramps / Rohnert Park Expressway (signalized - Caltrans)
                      6. Rohnert Park Expressway / Commerce Boulevard (signalized)
                      7. Rohnert Park Expressway / Snyder Lane (signalized)
                      8. Rohnert Park Expy. / North Sonoma State University (SSU) Access (SSU stop control)
                      9. Rohnert Park Expressway / Petaluma Hill Road (signalized)
                      10. East Cotati Avenue / Snyder Lane (signalized)
                      11. East Cotati Avenue / Old Redwood Highway (signalized ­ City of Cotati)
                      12. Adobe Road / Petaluma Hill Road (signalized ­ Sonoma County / Penngrove)
                      13. Main Street / Old Redwood Highway (signalized ­ Sonoma County / Penngrove)
                      14. Rohnert Park Expressway / Kerry Road (Project Only)
                      15. Rohnert Park Expressway / Twin Creeks Road (Project Only)



                  The peak time periods analyzed are as follows:
                      ·    Weekday a.m. (7:00-9:00 a.m.)
                      ·    Weekday p.m. (4:00-6:00 p.m.)

                  This study addresses the following four (4) traffic scenarios:
                      1. Existing Conditions ­ This scenario evaluates operational conditions at the study
                          intersections based on collected existing (year 2012) traffic counts and the existing
                          roadway network, as well as field surveys. This scenario corresponds to the 2012 baseline
                          scenario in the UDSP EIR.
                      2. Existing plus Proposed Project Conditions ­ This scenario is identical to Existing plus
                          Approved Projects Conditions, but with the addition of traffic expected to be generated by
                          the proposed Vast Oak and University District LLC Mixed-Use Development. This scenario
                          corresponds to the 2012 plus Specific Plan Buildout scenario in the UDSP EIR.
                      3. 2020 Baseline Conditions - This scenario evaluates operational conditions at the study
                          intersections based on a projection of existing traffic volumes eight years into the future.
                          Projections were derived from 2020 projections contained in the University District
                          Specific Plan environmental impact report (UDSP EIR). Traffic estimates include both
                          regional traffic growth and growth due to development buildout within the City of Rohnert
                          Park. This scenario corresponds to the 2020 baseline scenario in the UDSP EIR.


                 Final Report ­ Traffic Impact Study for University District LLC & Vast Oak Properties            Page 7
                 in the City of Rohnert Park                                                             January 3, 2014
        TJKM
Transportation
   Consultants

                      4. 2020 plus Proposed Project Conditions - This scenario is identical to 2020 Baseline
                         Conditions, but with the addition of traffic expected to be generated by the proposed
                         project. This scenario corresponds to the 2020 plus Specific Plan Buildout scenario in the
                         UDSP EIR.

                  Level of Service Analysis Methodology
                  Traffic impacts on the study roadways and intersections were quantified through the determination
                  of level of service (LOS), a qualitative measure describing operational conditions within a traffic
                  stream. There are six levels of service defined for each type of facility (i.e., roadway or intersection)
                  that is analyzed. LOS has letter designations ranging from A to F, with LOS A representing the best
                  operating conditions and LOS F the worst. Procedures for analyzing each type of facility are based
                  on the Highway Capacity Manual 2000 (HCM 2000). Generally speaking, for intersections, average
                  delay per vehicle is the quantitative measure that is used to determine LOS.
                  Signalized Intersections
                  For the signalized study intersections, operating conditions and LOS are evaluated using the 2000
                  Highway Capacity Manual (HCM) Operations Method as incorporated in the Synchro traffic
                  software. Peak hour intersection conditions are reported as average delay per vehicle with
                  corresponding levels of service for the intersection as a whole. The methodology is described in
                  detail in Appendix A.
                  Unsignalized Intersections
                  For the unsignalized study intersections, operating conditions and LOS are evaluated using the 2000
                  HCM Unsignalized Intersections methodology as incorporated in the Synchro traffic software. The
                  method ranks the LOS on an A through F scale similar to that used for signalized intersections, using
                  average delay in seconds for stopping movements as its measure of effectiveness. Peak hour
                  intersection conditions are reported as average delay per vehicle with corresponding levels of
                  service for the stopped approaches. The methodologies for unsignalized intersections are also
                  presented in Appendix A.

                  Significant Impact Criteria
                  As detailed in the 2006 University District Specific Plan (UDSP) environmental impact report
                  (EIR) and City of Rohnert Park General Plan, all City of Rohnert Park study intersections and
                  roadway segments are subject to a level of service (LOS) threshold of LOS C, except for the
                  Rohnert Park Expressway / Snyder Lane study intersection, where the General Plan designates
                  LOS D as acceptable. The Rohnert Park thresholds do not distinguish between signals and other
                  intersection traffic control types. The study intersections in Sonoma County and the City of Cotati
                  are also subject to a threshold of LOS D.

                  The Rohnert Park LOS policy further states that LOS D or lower operation is acceptable for an
                  intersection that operates at LOS D or lower at the time an application for a development project is
                  submitted if there are no feasible improvements to achieve a higher LOS. The existing LOS may not,
                  however, deteriorate further due to the proposed development project.

                  Additional considerations were made in applying Rohnert Park significance criteria. Where the
                  addition of proposed project traffic is expected to cause a low-volume minor approach of an
                  intersection to exceed LOS C (Rohnert Park threshold), there is the potential for unwarranted
                  mitigations that may actually create undue delay or maintenance expenses, such as a traffic signal or
                  additional turn lanes. The Sonoma County Guidelines for Traffic Studies provide further guidance,

                 Final Report ­ Traffic Impact Study for University District LLC & Vast Oak Properties                Page 8
                 in the City of Rohnert Park                                                                 January 3, 2014
        TJKM
Transportation
   Consultants

                  stating that LOS F is not necessarily considered a significant impact on minor approaches with 30 or
                  fewer peak hour vehicles per approach or left-turn lane. Thus, a traffic signal in these cases was
                  only considered if any minor intersection approach deteriorated to LOS F with project traffic
                  and/or if peak hour signal warrants were met.

                  Lastly, TJKM applied Caltrans freeway significance criteria to this project. Caltrans maintains a
                  target LOS at the transition between LOS C and LOS D for freeway facilities, which translates to a
                  service flow rate of approximately 1,680 passenger cars per mile per lane. Where an existing
                  freeway is operating at less than the LOS C/D threshold an existing "measure of effectiveness"
                  should be maintained. In determining whether a project would create an adverse impact to a
                  freeway facility already operating at LOS E or F, the forecast service flow rate was compared to
                  ideal freeway capacity to establish a theoretical volume-to-capacity (v/c) ratio. A significant
                  cumulative impact is considered to occur if a project would increase the freeway v/c ratio on a
                  facility already operating at LOS E or F by 0.01 or more.




                 Final Report ­ Traffic Impact Study for University District LLC & Vast Oak Properties            Page 9
                 in the City of Rohnert Park                                                             January 3, 2014
        TJKM
Transportation
   Consultants

                  Existing Conditions

                  Roadway Network
                  The local circulation system serving the project site is shown in Figure 1. Rohnert Park Expressway
                  and Keiser Avenue would provide primary local access to the project site.

                  US 101, located west the project site, is a four-lane, controlled-access freeway of statewide
                  importance. The freeway provides access to Mendocino County to the north and Marin County
                  and the City of San Francisco to the south. The nearest interchange is located at Rohnert Park
                  Expressway directly west of the project site. Recently, high-occupancy vehicle (HOV) lanes were
                  opened for two widening projects in the study area vicinity, Central (Old Redwood Highway in
                  Petaluma to Rohnert Park Expressway) and Wilfred (Rohnert Park Expressway to Santa Rosa
                  Avenue). The US 101 / Wilfred interchange is currently being reconstructed. The completed HOV
                  lanes (one per direction) operate during designated weekday a.m. and p.m. commute hours.

                  Rohnert Park Expressway is a four- to six-lane arterial roadway running east-west that connects the
                  project site to the US 101 freeway and provides access to Rohnert Park neighborhoods east and
                  west of the freeway. It will form the southern boundary of the Vast Oak properties and northern
                  boundary of the UDLLC property.

                  Petaluma Hill Road is a two-lane, north-south arterial roadway that forms the eastern border of the
                  project site. The roadway connects Penngrove to the south and Santa Rosa to the north.

                  East Cotati Avenue is a two-lane, east-west secondary arterial that provides access to U.S. 101, the
                  City of Cotati, and eastern portions of the City of Rohnert Park. Snyder Lane and Commerce
                  Boulevard are both north-south secondary arterials.

                  Keiser Avenue is a two-lane, local road that forms the northern boundary of the project site. It
                  connects Snyder Lane to the west with Petaluma Hill Road to the east. This roadway will also
                  provide local access to the project via driveways.

                  Existing Pedestrian and Bicycle Facilities
                  TJKM reviewed pedestrian and bicycle conditions along street segments bordering the project
                  site. Currently, the roadways bordering the project site do not include sidewalks or other
                  pedestrian facilities. In the vicinity, there are sidewalks located on both sides of Snyder Lane
                  between Creekside Middle School and Rohnert Park Expressway, although there are no
                  sidewalks north of the school on the east side of the roadway. There are also two multi-use
                  paths for pedestrians and bicyclists - one located south of Rohnert Park Expressway between
                  Snyder Lane and Jasmine Circle, and another located adjacent to Copeland Creek extending from
                  Sonoma State University to Commerce Boulevard. Sidewalks are also provided along both sides
                  of Rohnert Park Expressway west of Snyder Lane, extending through the city limits.

                  Bicycle facilities are classified in three ways: off-street paths separated from auto traffic (Class I),
                  on-street striped lanes (Class II), and on-street signed routes in which bicycles share the roadway
                  with other vehicles (Class III). Currently, there are no official bicycle facilities along the project
                  frontages, although there are variable width (6-8 foot shoulders) on Rohnert Park Expressway
                  and Petaluma Hill Road bordering the project site that may be used by some cyclists. In addition
                  to the Class I multi-use paths referenced above, there are also Class II bicycle lanes located along
                  Snyder Lane near the project site.

                 Final Report ­ Traffic Impact Study for University District LLC & Vast Oak Properties              Page 10
                 in the City of Rohnert Park                                                                January 3, 2014
        TJKM
Transportation
   Consultants

                  Existing Transit Service
                  Sonoma County Transit (SCT) and Golden Gate Transit (GGT) provide public transportation
                  service to the City of Rohnert Park and within the local project area.

                  SCT Routes 10, 12, and 14 are local routes with daily and Saturday service connecting Rohnert
                  Park, Cotati, and Sonoma State University. Route 10 loops through Rohnert Park and Cotati
                  while Routes 12 and 14 are loops serving northern Rohnert Park. All three of these routes
                  intersect. These routes operate at 30-90 minute headways on weekdays and 105-minute headways
                  on Saturdays. Each route serves bus stops along Snyder Lane in the project vicinity.

                  GGT Route 80 operates daily between Santa Rosa and San Francisco during commute hours,
                  with a stop in Rohnert Park at Commerce Boulevard. Routes 72 and 74 also operate daily
                  between Santa Rosa and San Francisco and stop at the Rohnert Park Expressway park-and-ride
                  lot at US 101 during commute hours.

                  Existing Vehicle, Bicycle, and Pedestrian Volumes
                  Existing weekday a.m. and p.m. period vehicle, bicycle, and pedestrian volumes were collected at the
                  study intersections in October 2012, while local schools were in session. Figure 3 illustrates the
                  existing vehicle turning movement volumes for both peak hours at the study intersections, as well as
                  existing traffic controls and lane geometries. Traffic count data sheets are provided in Appendix B.

                  Intersection Level of Service Analysis ­ Existing Conditions
                  Table 1 below summarizes peak hour levels of service at the study intersections under Existing
                  Conditions. LOS worksheets are provided in Appendix C. Under Existing Conditions, all
                  intersections are operating within acceptable LOS standards, with the exception of the northbound
                  North SSU Access stop-controlled movement at Rohnert Park Expressway, which operates at LOS
                  E during the a.m. peak hour and LOS F during the p.m. peak hour. Also, the Adobe Road / Petaluma
                  Hill Road intersection operates at LOS F during the p.m. peak hour.

                  Freeway Mainline Analysis ­ Existing Conditions
                  TJKM analyzed the mainline freeway segments of US 101 between West Sierra Avenue and
                  Rohnert Park Expressway and between Rohnert Park Expressway and Santa Rosa Avenue during
                  the p.m. peak hour, consistent with the UDSP Final EIR. TJKM used existing US 101 freeway
                  mainline volumes published by Caltrans and collected ramp volumes to conduct the freeway
                  mainline analysis for Existing Conditions. Table 2 below shows LOS for the study freeway
                  segments under Existing Conditions. Currently, both study freeway segments are operating at LOS
                  C in the southbound direction. In the northbound direction, the freeway segment of Rohnert Park
                  Expressway and Santa Rosa Avenue is operating at LOS F, which exceeds Caltrans LOS standards.
                  LOS worksheets are provided in Appendix G.

                  Existing plus Proposed Project Conditions

                  Project Proposal
                  The proposed Vast Oak (VO) and University District LLC (UD LLC) Mixed-Use Development
                  would be developed on five currently vacant parcels (VO West, VO Central, VO East, VO North
                  and UD LLC) along Rohnert Park Expressway north of the Sonoma State University (SSU)
                  campus and Green Music Center (GMC) and west of Petaluma Hill Road. The full-build proposed
                  project will consist of 1,236 single-family homes ranging from low- to high-density, 218 below
                  market rate (BMR) apartments, and 100,000 square feet of neighborhood-serving commercial
                  retail (VO East). The project would be built in five phases, and the parcels are expected to be
                  completed in the following order: VO West, VO Central, VO East, VO North and UD LLC.
                  According to the site plan, the project would provide multiple access points to Rohnert Park
                  Expressway and Keiser Avenue. Traffic signals will be installed at intersection of Rohnert Park
                  Expressway/Twin Creeks Road and the intersection of Rohnert Park Expressway/Kerry Road.

                  For purposes of comparison with the 2006 UDSP, the proposed project unit count under
                  consideration includes 191 single-family units proposed to be built on non-VO/UD LLC parcels
                  within the UDSP. They are the Linden, Gee, and Cotati-Rohnert Park Unified School District
                  (CRPUSD) parcels.

                  It should be noted that these collective developments were approved as part of the 2006 UDSP
                  and now represent an amendment to the UDSP given adjustments that have been made with
                  regard to building product types, building site locations within the UDSP area, and overall project
                  phasing.

                  Project Trip Generation
                  TJKM developed estimated project trip generation for the proposed project based on the published
                  trip generation rates from the Institute of Transportation Engineers' (ITE) publication Trip Generation
                  (8th Edition). TJKM also followed the guidance of ITE's Trip Generation Handbook (2nd Edition) in terms
                  of applying average trip rates or fitted curve rate equations for each proposed land use, as well as
                  applying pass-by trip discounts for the proposed retail use. For purposes of the traffic analysis and
                  based on guidance from City staff, the second units were treated as an ITE apartment use.

                  TJKM applied internal trip and pass-by trip discounts to the proposed project uses that were
                  originally estimated in the UDSP EIR. Specifically for daily trips, a 14 percent internal trip discount
                  was applied to development parcels within a 1/4-mile walking distance of the proposed commercial
                  retail core, whereas a seven percent internal trip discount was applied to parcels between 1/4-mile
                  and one-mile distance. Similarly for peak hour trips, a 13 percent internal trip discount was applied
                  to development parcels within a 1/4-mile walking distance of the proposed commercial retail core,
                  whereas a six percent peak hour internal trip discount was applied to parcels between 1/4-mile and
                  one-mile distance. An 18 percent vehicle pass-by rate was also applied to trips expected to be
                  generated by the commercial retail use.

                  Table 3 shows the trip generation expected to be generated by the proposed project. With the
                  application of internal trip discounts to all project land uses and pass-by trip discounts to all
                  commercial retail land uses according to the UDSP EIR and Trip Generation Handbook guidance, the
                  proposed project is expected to generate approximately 16,274 weekday daily trips (8,137 both
                  inbound and outbound), 1,118 weekday a.m. peak hour trips (303 inbound, 815 outbound), and 1,662


                 Final Report ­ Traffic Impact Study for University District LLC & Vast Oak Properties              Page 14
                 in the City of Rohnert Park                                                                January 3, 2014
        TJKM
Transportation
   Consultants

                  weekday p.m. peak hour trips (1,016 inbound, 646 outbound). When compared to the total project
                  trips analyzed in the 2006 UDSP EIR, the current project results in 2,361 fewer daily trips and 181
                  fewer p.m. peak hour trips.

                  Project Trip Distribution and Assignment
                  TJKM developed trip distribution assumptions for the proposed project based on distributions
                  contained in the UDSP EIR, with minor adjustments made based on 2012 traffic counts and
                  knowledge of the study area. Project trips were assigned to the existing roadway network based
                  on the above distribution and added to Existing Conditions turning movement counts. The
                  assumed project trip distributions and resulting assigned trips are illustrated in Figure 4. The
                  resulting study intersection volumes for Existing plus Proposed Project Conditions are shown in
                  Figure 5.

                  Intersection Level of Service Analysis ­ Existing plus Proposed Project Conditions
                  Table 4 summarizes peak hour levels of service at the study intersections under Existing plus
                  Proposed Project Conditions. LOS worksheets are provided in Appendix D. It is assumed under
                  this scenario that a traffic signal will be installed at the intersection of Rohnert Park Expressway
                  and Twin Creeks Road.

                  Under Existing plus Proposed Project Conditions, most intersections would continue operating
                  acceptably, with the following exceptions:
                      ·    Snyder Lane / Keiser Avenue: LOS D/C to LOS F/F (AM/PM) for the minor westbound
                           approach.
                      ·    Rohnert Park Expressway / North SSU Access: LOS E/F to LOS F/F for the minor
                           northbound approach.
                      ·    Adobe Road / Petaluma Hill Road: with the addition of project traffic, this intersection
                           would continue to operate unacceptably at LOS F during the p.m. peak hour, with an
                           increase of 24.1 seconds in delay.

                  Mitigation Measures ­ Existing plus Proposed Project Conditions
                  Based on the preceding Existing plus Project traffic analysis, it is expected that the proposed
                  project would cause significant impacts with respect to traffic at the following intersections:
                      ·    Snyder Lane / Keiser Avenue: LOS D/C to LOS F/F (AM/PM) for the minor westbound
                           approach. This is a significant impact based on applicable LOS criteria. The UDSP prescribes
                           installation of a traffic signal (TRA-4a), which if implemented as a mitigation measure as part
                           of the UDSP project would improve intersection operations to LOS B/A (AM/PM), thereby
                           resulting in a less than significant impact, consistent with the UDSP EIR.
                      ·    Rohnert Park Expressway / North SSU Access: LOS E/F to LOS F/F for the minor
                           northbound approach. This is a significant impact based on applicable LOS criteria. The
                           UDSP prescribes installation of a westbound left turn pocket and two-way left-turn lane
                           (TRA-1a) plus a traffic signal (TRA-7a). If both mitigation measures are implemented, the
                           intersection would improve to LOS C/C (AM/PM), thereby resulting in a less than
                           significant impact consistent with the UDSP EIR. The proposed project impact is expected
                           to be similar to the comparable LOS reported in the 2006 UDSP EIR, given that actual 2012
                           traffic volumes collected and analyzed in this study are higher than the estimated 2012
                           traffic levels in the UDSP EIR, thereby resulting in a higher baseline delay when compared
                           to the 2006 UDSP EIR.
                      ·    Adobe Road / Petaluma Hill Road: with the addition of project traffic, this intersection
                           would continue to operate unacceptably at LOS F during the p.m. peak hour, with an
                           increase of 24.1 seconds in delay. Since delay would increase by more than five seconds
                           under an unacceptable LOS F condition, the proposed project would cause a significant
                           impact consistent with the UDSP EIR. If an additional through lane were added in both the
                           northbound and southbound directions of Petaluma Hill Road, p.m. peak hour LOS would
                           improve to LOS D. However, this improvement is subject to a feasibility evaluation, and
                           Sonoma County has not identified this or any other transportation improvement for this
                           intersection. Therefore, consistent with the UDSP EIR, this impact is significant and
                           unavoidable. On an intersection average delay basis, this impact is less than that reported in
                           the UDSP EIR for year 2012. Consistent with UDSP EIR mitigation TRA-9a, TJKM
                           recommends coordination between Sonoma County and the City of Rohnert Park to
                           determine a fair-share portion of funds to alleviate congestion at this intersection and, if
                           appropriate, collection of a fair-share allocation from the project sponsor.
                  Freeway Analysis ­ Existing plus Project Conditions
                  Table 5 below shows LOS results for the study freeway segments under Existing plus Project
                  Conditions for the p.m. peak hour. LOS worksheets are provided in Appendix G. With the addition
                  of project volumes, both study freeway segments are expected to continue operating at LOS C in
                  the southbound direction during the p.m. peak hour. In the northbound direction, both freeway
                  segments are expected to operate at LOS E or worse during the p.m. peak hour.

                  Table 5: Freeway Mainline Levels of Service ­ Existing Plus Project Conditions
                                                                            Existing Conditions          Existing Plus Project Conditions
                   US 101 Freeway Segment (PM Peak Hour)                 NB                 SB                 NB                SB
                                                                   Volume      LOS    Volume      LOS    Volume    LOS    Volume    LOS
                    West Sierra Ave. to Rohnert Park Expwy.         2,324       E      1,683      C      2,347      E      1,744     C
                    Rohnert Park Expwy. To Santa Rosa Ave.          2,502       F      1,668      C      2,578      F      1,716     C
                      Notes:   Freeway results are expressed as Service Flow Rate/Level of Service
                               Freeway Service Flow Rate is measured in passenger cars per hour per lane
                               LOS = Level of Service, NB = Northbound; SB = Southbound

                  The increases in the freeway volume to capacity (v/c) ratios associated with the project volumes
                  are shown below in Table 6. An increase of 0.01 in v/c ratio on freeway segments already operating
                  at LOS E or F is considered to be a significant impact. Based on expected v/c ratio increases, the
                  proposed project would cause significant impacts on the northbound segments of West Sierra
                  Avenue to Rohnert Park Expressway and Rohnert Park Expressway to Santa Rosa Avenue.

                  Table 6: Freeway Mainline V/C Ratio Changes ­ Existing Plus Project Conditions
                                                                                           Existing Plus Project
                                                                   Existing Conditions                                      Change to V/C Ratio
                   US 101 Freeway Segment (PM Peak Hour)                                        Conditions
                                                                      NB         SB          NB                SB             NB         SB
                    West Sierra Ave. to Rohnert Park Expwy.           1.01       0.73        1.02              0.76           0.01       0.03
                    Rohnert Park Expwy. To Santa Rosa Ave.            1.09       0.73        1.12              0.75           0.03       0.02
                      Notes:   V/C = Volume to Capacity Ratio
                               Ideal freeway capacity assumed to be 2,300 vehicles per hour per lane within study area

                  The City of Rohnert Park, County of Sonoma, and Sonoma County Transportation Authority
                  (SCTA) all recognize that the US 101 freeway will experience congestion into the foreseeable
                  future, and mitigations such as expansions or new freeways are unlikely to be built. Because there
                  are no known freeway capacity improvements that would result in acceptable operation in the
                  future, and subsequently no means for the proposed project to contribute a fair-share payment for
                  impacts to the US 101 freeway, the above impacts are considered significant and unavoidable.

                  Recommended Turn Pocket Lengths ­ Existing Plus Project Conditions
                  TJKM estimated necessary turn pocket lengths along Rohnert Park Expressway at the study
                  intersections providing access to the project site under Existing plus Project Conditions. Table 7
                  shows expected 95th percentile (maximum) queue lengths for specific turning movements at the
                  project study intersections under Existing Plus Project Conditions. When determining a proposed
                  pocket length, an additional 30 feet was added to account for the taper transition. Table 8 shows
                  the recommended turn pocket lengths including taper under Existing Plus Project Conditions.

                  Project Consistency with Alternative Mode Transportation Policies and Plans
                  TJKM evaluated the circulation plan of the proposed Vast Oak (VO) and University District LLC
                  (UD LLC) Mixed-Use Development in terms of connectivity to the current pedestrian, bicycle, and
                  public transit facilities within the project vicinity and consistency with current City alternative
                  transportation mode policies.

                  Currently, Rohnert Park Expressway from the US 101 freeway to the western limit of the
                  proposed project is classified as a Class II bikeway (on-street, striped bicycle lanes separate from
                  vehicular travel lanes, parking lanes, bus stops, and sidewalks). Snyder Lane is currently a Class II
                  bikeway and includes multiple bicycle racks along the corridor. There are also existing bicycle racks
                  at the intersection of Rohnert Park Expressway and Snyder Lane. In the future, Sonoma County
                  Transportation Authority (SCTA) anticipates a Class II facility on Petaluma Hill Road, as well as a
                  Class II bikeway on Rohnert Park Expressway adjacent to the proposed project site.

                  Sonoma County Transit operates three public transit routes near the project site. Route 12 serves
                  Snyder Lane, Country Club Drive, and Rohnert Park Expressway in the project vicinity on
                  weekdays and Saturdays. Routes 10 and 14 provide service along Snyder Lane in the project
                  vicinity, operating on weekdays and Saturdays. The transit stops closest to the project site are at
                  the intersection of Rohnert Park Expressway and Snyder Lane, which is served by these transit
                  routes.

                  In terms of alternative transportation facility provision, the project sponsor will provide Class I (off-
                  street) pathways along Hinebaugh Creek within the project site that will connect to the existing
                  creek trails located to the west. Class II bikeways are proposed to be on Twin Creeks Road,
                  Killarney Road, Kelso Road, and Kerry Road from Rohnert Park Expressway to Killarney Road
                  within the project site. Also, the project sponsor has committed to providing additional bus stops
                  within the proposed project site along Rohnert Park Expressway to promote access to the local
                  public transit system.

                  The Rohnert Park General Plan contains the following pedestrian and bicycle circulation goals:

                      ·    Promote safe, efficient, and comfortable circulation for cyclists and pedestrians throughout
                           Rohnert Park.
                      ·    Create pedestrian-friendly activity centers that encourage local walking trips between to
                           and from adjacent uses.
                      ·    Provide continuous, direct pedestrian routes and bikeways between and through
                           neighborhoods and activity centers, and job centers and residential areas, including the
                           University District, the City Center, and commercial and industrial areas.
                      ·    Provide pedestrian routes and bikeways that link residential areas to city parks and open
                           space areas outside the city.
                 Final Report ­ Traffic Impact Study for University District LLC & Vast Oak Properties                       Page 21
                 in the City of Rohnert Park                                                                         January 3, 2014
        TJKM
Transportation
   Consultants

                      ·    Continue to develop a comprehensive network of bikeways that promote bicycle riding for
                           transportation and recreation.
                      ·    Provide adequate bicycle parking facilities.

                  The bicycle lanes proposed within the project site adheres to the goals of the Rohnert Park
                  General Plan, as they will connect with proposed bicycle lanes along Rohnert Park Expressway
                  adjacent to the project site. The proposed Class I bikeway along Hinebaugh Creek through the
                  project site follows the goal of linking residential areas to open space areas.

                  2020 Baseline Conditions

                  This section details expected traffic conditions at the study intersections under 2020 Baseline
                  Conditions. This analysis scenario is defined as baseline conditions in Year 2020 that assume no
                  development at the project site.

                  Future Baseline Development Assumptions
                  According to City staff and based on review of the UDSP EIR and other documents, there are
                  several specific plans and developments in the vicinity of the proposed project that are expected to
                  be completed by year 2020 and as such are included in the 2020 baseline traffic projections. The
                  following plans and developments are anticipated by 2020 and are expected to add traffic to the
                  study area intersections:
                       1. Southeast Specific Plan
                       2. Northeast Specific Plan ­ subject to future amendment per discussion with City staff.
                       3. Northwest Specific Plan ­ subject to future amendment per discussion with City staff.
                       4. Wilfred Dowdell Specific Plan
                       5. Stadium Lands
                       6. Sonoma Mountain Village Development
                       7. Graton Rancheria Casino (450,000 square feet with 300-room hotel)
                       8. Green Music Center on SSU campus (completed and opened in 2012)
                       9. SSU Campus Expansion
                       10. Kisco Development (Oakview Terrace Apartments) Phase 2 - 90 Units
                       11. State Farm - 29 acres. The site is currently zoned as office and is currently being analyzed
                           as part of the Central Rohnert Park Priority Development Area (PDA), which is currently
                           in progress.

                  Year 2020 Traffic Estimates
                  TJKM developed Year 2020 study area intersection traffic volumes based on the 2020 traffic volume
                  estimates contained in the UDSP EIR. Given the slow pace of development growth over the last
                  several years, this was considered a reasonable (and possibly conservative) approach. TJKM used
                  the 2020 UDSP buildout volumes as a starting point to estimate a 2020 baseline for this study.
                  Expected project traffic volumes were backed out of the 2020 UDSP buildout volumes to estimate
                  2020 Baseline Conditions volumes. In cases where 2020 Baseline Conditions volumes fell below
                  Existing Conditions traffic volumes, TJKM raised such volumes to the Existing Conditions level to
                  ensure a conservative (worst-case) traffic estimate. Then, project traffic volumes were added back
                  to 2020 Baseline Conditions to generate 2020 plus Project traffic volumes for analysis.

                  Figure 6 shows the 2020 Baseline traffic volumes at the study intersections resulting from the
                  above traffic estimates and area approved development traffic. This figure also shows expected
                  baseline traffic controls and lane geometries at the study intersections prior to project
                  implementation.

                 in the City of Rohnert Park                                                              January 3, 2014

   Consultants

                  Intersection Level of Service Analysis Results (2020 Baseline Conditions)
                  Table 9 summarizes the results of the LOS analysis conducted for the study intersections under
                  2020 Baseline Conditions. Detailed calculation sheets are contained in Appendix E. All intersections
                  are expected to operate within acceptable LOS standards, with the following exceptions:

                         ·   Snyder Lane / Keiser Avenue (LOS F both peak hours for westbound approach)
                         ·   Petaluma Hill Road / Keiser Avenue (LOS F both peak hours for eastbound approach)
                         ·   Rohnert Park Expressway / Snyder Lane (LOS E during a.m. peak hour)
                         ·   Rohnert Park Expressway / North SSU Access (LOS F during both peak hours)
                         ·   E. Cotati Avenue / Old Redwood Highway (LOS F during p.m. peak hour)
                         ·   Adobe Road / Petaluma Hill Road (LOS F both peak hours)
                         ·   Main Street / Old Redwood Highway (LOS F during a.m. peak hour and LOS E during p.m.
                             peak hour)

                  Freeway Mainline Analysis ­ 2020 Baseline Conditions
                  TJKM analyzed the mainline freeway segments of Highway 101 between West Sierra Avenue and
                  Rohnert Park Expressway and between Rohnert Park Expressway and Santa Rosa Avenue during
                  the p.m. peak hour under 2020 Baseline Conditions. TJKM used future year volumes contained in
                  the UDSP Final EIR for analysis. Table 10 below shows LOS results for the study freeway segments
                  under 2020 Baseline Conditions. LOS worksheets are provided in Appendix G. Both freeway
                  mainline segments are expected to operate at LOS D or better in the southbound direction during
                  the p.m. peak hour. In the northbound direction, both freeway segments are operating at LOS E or
                  worse during the p.m. peak hour.

                  2020 plus Project Conditions

                  This analysis scenario is identical to 2020 Baseline Conditions, but with the addition of traffic
                  generated by the proposed Vast Oak and University District LLC Mixed-Use Development. Trip
                  generation, distribution, and assignment for the proposed project are identical to that assumed
                  under Existing plus Proposed Project Conditions. Figure 7 shows 2020 plus Project traffic volumes, lane
                  geometries, and traffic controls. Under this scenario, it is assumed that a traffic signal will be in place at
                  the project intersection of Rohnert Park Expressway and Twin Creeks Road.

                  Intersection Level of Service Analysis Results (2020 plus Project Conditions)
                  The LOS analysis results for both 2020 Baseline and 2020 plus Project Conditions are summarized
                  in Table 11. Detailed calculations are contained in Appendix F. The following intersections are
                  expected to operate unacceptably:
                      ·    Snyder Lane / Keiser Avenue (LOS F both peak hours for westbound approach with added
                           average delay)
                      ·    Petaluma Hill Road / Keiser Avenue (LOS F both peak hours for eastbound approach with
                           added average delay)
                      ·    Rohnert Park Expressway / Snyder Lane (LOS D to LOS E during both peak hours)
                      ·    Rohnert Park Expressway / North SSU Access (LOS F during both peak hours with added
                           average delay)
                      ·    Rohnert Park Expressway / Petaluma Hill Road (change from LOS C to unacceptable
                           LOS E during both peak hours)
                      ·    E. Cotati Avenue / Old Redwood Highway (LOS D/E to LOS E during both peak hours)
                      ·    Adobe Road / Petaluma Hill Road (LOS F both peak hours with added average delay)
                      ·    Main Street / Old Redwood Highway (LOS F/E to LOS F/E with added average delay)

                  Mitigation Measures ­ 2020 plus Proposed Project Conditions
                  Based on the preceding 2020 plus Proposed Project traffic analysis, it is expected that the
                  proposed project would cause significant impacts with respect to traffic at the following
                  intersections:
                      · Snyder Lane / Keiser Avenue (LOS F both peak hours for westbound approach with added
                          average delay). This is a significant impact given that additional delay would be added to an
                          intersection already operating at LOS F in the 2020 baseline condition. With the
                          implementation of the prescribed UDSP EIR improvement of a traffic signal (TRA-4a), service
                          levels would be improved to LOS C during both peak hours. The result would be a less than
                          significant impact, consistent with the UDSP EIR. The mitigation is also consistent with the
                          UDSP EIR. Petaluma Hill Road / Keiser Avenue (LOS F both peak hours for eastbound
                          approach with added average delay). This is a significant impact given that additional delay
                          would be added to an intersection already operating at LOS F in the 2020 baseline condition.
                          With the implementation of the prescribed UDSP EIR improvements of separate left and
                          right turn lanes for the eastbound Keiser Avenue approach, a center turn lane on Petaluma
                          Hill Road adjacent to Keiser Avenue, and signalization of the intersection (TRA-5a,5b, and
                          14a respectively), service levels would improve to LOS B during both peak hours. The result
                          would be a less than significant impact, consistent with the UDSP EIR. The mitigation is also
                          consistent with the UDSP EIR.
                      · Rohnert Park Expressway / Snyder Lane (LOS D to LOS E during both peak hours). This is a
                          significant impact. With the implementation of the prescribed UDSP EIR improvements to
                          widen Snyder Lane between Keiser Avenue and Southwest Boulevard and to reconfigure the
                          Rohnert Park Expressway / Snyder Lane intersection (TRA-6a and 6b, respectively), service
                          levels are expected to improve to LOS C during both peak hours. The result would be a less
                          than significant impact, consistent with the UDSP EIR. The mitigation is also consistent with
                          the UDSP EIR.




                 Final Report ­ Traffic Impact Study for University District LLC & Vast Oak Properties                                  Page 31
                 in the City of Rohnert Park                                                                                    January 3, 2014
        TJKM
Transportation
   Consultants

                      ·    Rohnert Park Expressway / North SSU Access (LOS F during both peak hours with added
                           average delay). This is a significant impact. With the UDSP mitigation (TRA-7a) of installing
                           a traffic signal and associated geometric improvements, service levels are expected to
                           improve to LOS C during both peak hours. The result would be a less than significant
                           impact, consistent with the UDSP EIR. The mitigation is also consistent with the UDSP EIR.
                      ·    Rohnert Park Expressway / Petaluma Hill Road (change from acceptable LOS C to
                           unacceptable LOS E during both peak hours). This change in LOS represents a significant
                           impact. With the UDSP mitigation of adding an eastbound lane to allow for exclusive left and
                           right turn lanes at the intersection and an exclusive southbound right turn lane TRA-8a),
                           service levels are expected to improve to LOS C during both peak hours, resulting in a less
                           than significant impact, consistent with the UDSP EIR. The mitigation is also consistent with
                           the UDSP EIR.
                      ·    E. Cotati Avenue / Old Redwood Highway (LOS D/E to LOS E/F). With the addition of
                           project traffic, service levels would worsen from LOS D to E during the a.m. peak hour and
                           delay would increase under the LOS E condition during the p.m. peak hour. With the
                           addition of a second southbound left turn lane, service levels are expected to improve to
                           LOS D in both peak hours. However, this improvement is not programmed by the City of
                           Cotati and is subject to a feasibility analysis. Therefore, this impact remains significant and
                           unavoidable. Consistent with UDSP EIR mitigation TRA-18a, TJKM recommends
                           coordination between the Cities of Rohnert Park and Cotati to determine a fair-share
                           portion of funds to alleviate congestion at this intersection and, if appropriate, collection
                           of a fair-share allocation from the project sponsor.
                      ·    Adobe Road / Petaluma Hill Road (LOS F both peak hours with added average delay). With
                           the addition of project traffic, delay would worsen and exacerbate LOS F baseline conditions.
                           This is a significant impact. A mitigation consisting of a second southbound left turn lane,
                           widened westbound approach with left turn and shared through-right turn lanes, and an
                           added northbound through lane would mitigate this condition to an acceptable LOS D during
                           both peak hours. However, this improvement is not programmed by Sonoma County and is
                           subject to a feasibility analysis. Therefore, this impact remains significant and unavoidable.
                           Consistent with UDSP EIR mitigation TRA-9a, TJKM recommends coordination between
                           Sonoma County and the City of Rohnert Park to determine a fair-share portion of funds
                           to alleviate congestion at this intersection and, if appropriate, collection of a fair-share
                           allocation from the project sponsor.
                      ·    Main Street / Old Redwood Highway (LOS F both peak hours with added average delay).
                           With the addition of project traffic, delay would worsen and exacerbate LOS F/E (AM/PM)
                           baseline conditions. This is a significant impact. A mitigation consisting of a second
                           southbound through lane and second northbound through lane is expected to result in an
                           acceptable LOS C during both peak hours. However, this improvement is not programmed
                           by Sonoma County and is subject to a feasibility analysis. Therefore, this impact remains
                           significant and unavoidable. Consistent with UDSP EIR mitigation TRA-9a, TJKM
                           recommends coordination between Sonoma County and the City of Rohnert Park to
                           determine a fair-share portion of funds to alleviate congestion at this intersection and, if
                           appropriate, collection of a fair-share allocation from the project sponsor.




                 Final Report ­ Traffic Impact Study for University District LLC & Vast Oak Properties               Page 32
                 in the City of Rohnert Park                                                                 January 3, 2014
        TJKM
Transportation
   Consultants

                  Freeway Analysis ­ 2020 plus Project Conditions
                  TJKM analyzed the mainline freeway segments of Highway 101 between West Sierra Avenue and
                  Rohnert Park Expressway and Rohnert Park Expressway and Santa Rosa Avenue under 2020 plus
                  Project Conditions during the p.m. peak hour. Table 12 below shows LOS results for the study
                  freeway segments under 2020 plus Project Conditions. Freeway LOS analysis worksheets for all
                  analysis scenarios are provided in Appendix G. With the addition of project volumes, both freeway
                  mainline segments are expected to continue operating at LOS D or better in the southbound
                  direction during the p.m. peak hour. In the northbound direction, both freeway segments are
                  expected to operate at LOS E or worse during the p.m. peak hour.

                  Table 12: Freeway Mainline Levels of Service ­ 2020 Plus Project Conditions

                                                                                2020 Conditions              2020 Plus Project Conditions

                     US 101 Freeway Segment (PM Peak Hour)
                                                                               NB                 SB                NB                     SB

                                                                         Vol        LOS   Vol          LOS   Vol         LOS         Vol         LOS

                       West Sierra Ave. to Rohnert Park Expwy.          2,367        E    1,674        C     2,457        F        1,708          C

                       Rohnert Park Expwy. To Santa Rosa Ave.           2,804        F    1,833        D     2,875        F        1,946          D
                      Notes:   Freeway results are expressed as Service Flow Rate/Level of Service
                               Freeway Service Flow Rate is measured in passenger cars per hour per lane
                               NB = Northbound, SB = Southbound

                  The increases in the freeway volume to capacity (v/c) ratios associated with the project volumes
                  are shown below in Table 13. An increase of 0.01 in v/c ratio on freeway segments already
                  operating at LOS E or F is considered to be a significant impact. Based on expected v/c ratio
                  increases, the proposed project would cause significant impacts on the northbound segments of
                  West Sierra Avenue to Rohnert Park Expressway and Rohnert Park Expressway to Santa Rosa
                  Avenue.

                  Table 13: Freeway Mainline V/C Ratio Changes ­ 2020 Plus Project Conditions
                                                                                            2020 Plus Project
                                                                    2020 Conditions                                      Change to V/C Ratio
                   US 101 Freeway Segment (PM Peak Hour)                                       Conditions
                                                                     NB          SB         NB               SB               NB                SB
                    West Sierra Ave. to Rohnert Park Expwy.           1.03       0.73        1.07            0.74             0.04              0.01
                    Rohnert Park Expwy. To Santa Rosa Ave.            1.22       0.80        1.25            0.85             0.03              0.05
                      Notes:   V/C = Volume to Capacity Ratio
                               Ideal freeway capacity assumed to be 2,300 vehicles per hour per lane within study area
                               NB = Northbound, SB = Southbound

                  The City of Rohnert Park, County of Sonoma, and Sonoma County Transportation Authority
                  (SCTA) all recognize that the US 101 freeway will experience congestion into the foreseeable
                  future, and mitigations such as expansions or new freeways are unlikely to be built. Because there
                  are no known freeway capacity improvements that would result in acceptable operation in the
                  future, and subsequently no means for the proposed project to contribute a fair-share payment for
                  impacts to US 101 freeway, the above impacts are considered significant and unavoidable.




                 Final Report ­ Traffic Impact Study for University District LLC & Vast Oak Properties                                 Page 33
                 in the City of Rohnert Park                                                                                   January 3, 2014

   Consultants

                  Recommended Turn Pocket Lengths ­ 2020 Plus Project Conditions
                  TJKM estimated necessary turn pocket lengths along Rohnert Park Expressway at the study
                  intersections providing access to the project site under Existing plus Project Conditions. Table 14
                  shows expected 95th percentile (maximum) queue lengths for specific turning movements at
                  project study intersections under 2020 Plus Project Conditions. When determining a proposed
                  pocket length, an additional 30 feet was added to account for the taper transition. Table 15 shows
                  the recommended turn pocket lengths including taper under 2020 Plus Project Conditions.
